support_summary: HRD1 (also known as SYVN1) is a key E3 ubiquitin ligase in the ERAD pathway. VCP is recruited to the HRD1 complex to extract ubiquitinated substrates from the ER membrane for proteasomal degradation.

functions.cellular_process: HRD1 (SYVN1) is an ER-resident E3 ubiquitin ligase that is a central component of the ERAD machinery. It recognizes and ubiquitinates misfolded proteins in the ER lumen and membrane. VCP, along with its cofactors Ufd1 and Npl4, is recruited to the HRD1 complex. VCP then utilizes its ATPase activity to provide the mechanical force to extract the ubiquitinated substrates from the ER membrane, delivering them to the cytosol for degradation by the proteasome.
functions.effect_description: Forms a complex with VCP to mediate the extraction of ubiquitinated, misfolded proteins from the ER membrane for proteasomal degradation. HRD1 acts as the E3 ligase, and VCP provides the segregase/extraction function.
biological_consequence: Recognition of misfolded protein by HRD1 complex → HRD1-mediated ubiquitination of the substrate → Recruitment of the VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex → VCP-mediated extraction of the ubiquitinated substrate from the ER membrane → Proteasomal degradation of the substrate in the cytosol
specific_effects: HRD1 contains a VCP-binding motif (VBM) that facilitates its interaction with the N-terminal domain of VCP.
The VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex is essential for the retrotranslocation step in HRD1-mediated ERAD.
VCP acts as a core component of the HRD1 pathway, providing the necessary force for substrate dislocation.

evidence.paper_title: Different p97/VCP complexes function in retrotranslocation step of mammalian ER-associated degradation (ERAD)
evidence.relevant_quote: These results suggest that the Hrd1-mediated ERAD requires a well-established retrotranslocation machinery, the p97/VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex, whereas the gp78 pathway needs only p97/VCP and Npl4.

evidence.paper_title: Evolutionary divergence of valosin-containing protein/cell division cycle protein 48 binding interactions among endoplasmic reticulum-associated degradation proteins
evidence.relevant_quote: We report a VCP-binding motif (VBM) shared by mammalian ubiquitin ligase E4b (Ube4b)-ubiquitin fusion degradation protein 2a (Ufd2a), hydroxymethylglutaryl reductase degradation protein 1 (Hrd1)-synoviolin and ataxin 3... and show that Ube4b and Hrd1 compete for binding to the N-terminal domain of VCP.
